For example, the following is a nonlinear equation 3x^{2} + x = 2, because a polynomial of order n>1 will be nonlinear. If you have a function f(x) and you don't know if it's linear or not, check if f(ax+by)=af(x)+bf(y) holds or not --- this is the criteria of linearity.
The following equation is also nonlinear: x + yz =3. We cannot multiply two [or more] unknowns together in a linear equation.
So the following equation is nonlinear: x + y\cos (z) = 3, on two counts: first, \cos (z) is nonlinear; and second, y\cos (z) is not allowed in a linear equation.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Mule and donkey
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Elements of Algebra, Ch IV §4 question 3, par.612

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A mule and donkey carry a large load. The donkey complained of his load and said to the mule, "I need only 100 pounds of your load to make mine twice as heavy as yours would be." To which the mule answered, "But if you gave me 100 pounds of your load, I'd be carrying three times you would carry." How much did they carry?

Let d be the donkey's load, m be the mule's load. The donkey's statement could be presented in the equation, d + 100 = 2(m - 100), whereas the mule's response, m + 100 = 3(d - 100). From the first of these equations, we find d = 2m - 300. We plug this into the second equation to find \begin {split} m + 100 &= 3(2m - 400)\\ &= 6m - 1200. \end {split} Hence the mule carries, m = \frac {1300}{5} = 260~\hbox {pounds}, and this means the donkey carries, d = 520 - 300 = 220~\hbox {pounds}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Neo-Ricardian economics
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Piero Sraffa, Production of Commodities by Means of Commodities

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: (A "quarter" of wheat refers to an obscure measurement choice of 13th century England, because it can be found in the Magna Carta. By the 18th century, the measurement of 1 quarter of wheat in Britain varied port to port. It was finally standardized in 1824 to be 8 bushels (or 64 gallons).)

Note that this method for solving such equations in Neo-Ricardian economics works when there is no surplus; that is to say, when there is exactly as much produced (for each commodity) used as inputs in the economy. However, when there is a surplus, we need a more sophisticated technique because we will have a generalized eigenvalue problem.

Also note, as of 28 October 2022, it appears the going rate is 1.18925 quarters of wheat for 1 ton of iron. Well, 1 metric ton of iron ore traded for $93.010 whereas the USDA reported the price for 1 quarter (= 8 bushels) of wheat was approximately $73.68, which means that 1.26 quarters of wheat exchanged for 1 metric ton of iron.

As of 12 May 2025, it appears that 1 metric ton of iron ore is $98.19 (so 1 ton of iron is $89.07) and the price of 1 quarter (= 8 bushels) of wheat is $45.68, so the exchange rate is about 1.95 quarters wheat for 1 ton of iron (or 2.1495 quarters wheat for 1 metric ton of iron ore).
Although the value of iron ore appears to be relatively stable, the value of wheat fluctuates more wildly.

We will rely heavily on index notation. Why? Well, there are 26 possible symbols (using lowercase Latin letters), which means we could not discuss anything beyond systems of 5 equations in 5 variables; if we also use the 26 uppercase Latin letters, then we cannot discuss anything beyond systems of 7 equations in 7 unknowns. Rather than struggle with new symbols, we will use indices: appending numbers as subscripts to letters to refer to distinct quantities. Thus we write x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3} instead of x, y, z.

We may use Dummy Variables to affix a variable as a subscript, writing x_{i} where i could be 1, 2, or 3. Here i is the dummy variable in the expression x_{i}. We often will write "x_{i} where i=1,2,3" to indicate i is a dummy variable ranging over the values 1, 2, 3.

We can have several indices [plural of "index"] affixed to a symbol. We have seen this with coefficients, which had two indices separated by a comma. Some authors use a comma to separate indices, other authors do not.

Also we should note, some authors use superscripts indices. This will occur in some parts of mathematics, but we will avoid it in these notes whenever possible (because it's hard to tell if a superscript number is an exponent or an index).
A linear equation in one variable x looks like b = ax where a and b are real constants.
A single linear equation in two variables x and y looks like ax + by = c where a, b, and c are real constants.
A single linear equation in n variables x_{1}, …, x_{n} looks like a_{1}x_{1} + … + a_{n}x_{n} = b where a_{1}, …, a_{n}, and b are real constants.

A Solution to a system of equations in n variables x_{1}, …, x_{n} is an assignment of n real values s_{1}, …, s_{n} to the variables (so x_{1}=s_{1}, …, x_{n}=s_{n}) which satisfies the system of equations.

If you have a function f(x) and you don't know if it's linear or not, check if f(ax+by)=af(x)+bf(y) holds or not --- this is the criteria of linearity.
The following equation is also nonlinear: x + yz =3. We cannot multiply two [or more] unknowns together in a linear equation.
So the following equation is nonlinear: x + y\cos (z) = 3, on two counts: first, \cos (z) is nonlinear; and second, y\cos (z) is not allowed in a linear equation.

We backsubstitute this value for x_{3} into the second equation to obtain a value for x_{1}, then together these are backsubstituted into either the first or third equation of our original system to find the solution for x_{2}.

It does not tell us when a solution exists. There may not be a solution. Or, there may be infinitely many solutions (as we saw in Neo-Ricardian economics). It'd be nice to know before engaging in a computationally labourious process what we should expect.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Remember what a system of 1 linear equation in 1 variable looks like? We saw it was ax=b. We could solve this easily when a\neq 0, simply take x=b/a or x = a^{-1}b. It would be lovely if all systems of linear equations could be so easy.

We will try to make it easy by generalizing the notion of a "number". Instead of writing a system of equations as \begin {array}{rcl} a_{1,1}x_{1} + a_{1,2}x_{2} + … + a_{1,n}x_{n} &=& b_{1}\\ a_{2,1}x_{1} + a_{2,2}x_{2} + … + a_{2,n}x_{n} &=& b_{2}\\ \vdots \quad \qquad \vdots \quad \qquad \ddots \quad \qquad \vdots \quad & \vdots & \vdots \\ a_{m,1}x_{1} + a_{m,2}x_{2} + … + a_{m,n}x_{n} &=& b_{m} \end {array} we will introduce a notion of a matrix \mathbf {A} as an array of m rows and n columns, and vectors \vec {x}, \vec {b}, then rewrite our system as \mathbf {A}\vec {x}=\vec {b}. Just as with our simpler system with one equation in one unknown ax=b where we multiplied both sides by the number a^{-1} (assuming a is invertible), we can imitate this and try "multiplying" both sides by a matrix \mathbf {B} to transform our system to something like \vec {x} = \mathbf {B}\vec {b}. The problem: we will have to define a notion of matrix multiplication, and prove it satisfies the familiar properties which the multiplication of numbers enjoy.
